text: - Hello, everyone.
Welcome to another video on AWS databases.
My name is Mesgana Gormley.
I am a Senior Database Specialist
Solution Architect at AWS.

This is the second video
in a multi-part series
on Amazon RDS Custom for SQL server.

In this video, we are going
to work through step by step
on how you can create and connect
to your Amazon RDS Custom for SQL server.
Please check out upcoming videos
on additional information and deep dives
on RDS Custom high availability,
migration scenarios, and so on.
All right, let's get started.
Here is the agenda for this video.

I'll be spending more
time showing you a demo
on setting up the environment,
completing all the steps required
in order to successfully create RDS Custom
for SQL server instance,
and I will then create RDS Custom instance
and show you how you can connect to it
using RDP Client.
I will also show you how you can pause
and resume automation.

And then we'll see an example
of a support parameter.
If you are new to RDS Custom,

I highly encourage you to
check out the first video

in this series where I
cover the technical overview

and the use cases for RDS
Custom for SQL server.
Before we start creating instance,
let's talk about the steps required

in order to create RDS
Custom for SQL server.
The first requirement is KMS.

You must create a symmetric
customer master key.
The AWS managed key is not supported.

If you have an existing
KMS key in your account,
you can use that to create RDS Custom.
Next, you need to have an IAM role
and instance profile created as well.

You need to provide this IAM
role necessary permission

to access KMS key, S3 and
the other AWS services.
You will then add this IAM role
to your RDS Custom instant profile.
Next, you have to configure the VPC,

making sure that RDS
Custom can communicate

these other AWS services used
in the RDS Custom environment.
These services include CloudWatch, S3,
systems manager, and so on.
We covered this in the previous video.

If the RDS Custom cannot
reach any of these services,
your instance creation will fail.

Or if you already created
your instance successfully
and then it was running,

and at some point, for some
reason, RDS Custom loses access
to any of these services,

your instance will go to the
unsupported configuration.
You can create and configure
this required services manually,
but the easiest way will be to use

the cloud formation template
that's readily available
in our documentation.

I'll show you where those
are and then how you
can get that cloud formation template

so that way you don't have
to create and configure
this required services manually.

Once required services
are correctly configured,

you can simply create
the RDS Custom instance.

Once instance is in available
state, you can connect
to your instance using RDP client.

So to connect to the
database instance using RDP,
the VPC security group must allow
inbound traffic on port 3389.
Also, the underlying Amazon EC2 instance,

we need to have the
Windows firewall configured
so it can allow a remote desktop access.

We will use system
manager to run a command

that will configure the
firewall on the host for us.

Let me get into a demo now
to show you things in action.

Here is also the section

how you can create the

there are few additional

The first thing you need is this VPC

So we need to have public subnet.
For the public subnet to work,

create internet gateway

test environment running.

Then the other thing is
there is security group

The other rule is for super
server port for subset three.

to make is in the network ACL.

The network ACL currently

inbound and outbound connection

so that way I can connect

And one other thing I need to

in the public subnet
that I will be creating.

So those are the additional
steps that I need to complete

So the first step is going to VPC.

IGW RDS Custom Demo.

I'll create the internet gateway now.

This is our VPC, and click

That is created and then attached.
Next, I need to create the subnet.

That would be our RDS Custom Demo VPC.

10.0.112.0/20 is sufficient.
That's all I need to provide.

All right, go to the route table

currently only the local

So I'm gonna edit the route.
Click on add route

That is all for the route.

And it is this first one

To change the automation mode,

is automation section.
As you can see currently,
it's in full automation mode.
To pause it, I can click on the pause

that's actually the minimum.
You can pause it up to 24 hours.
So for now, I'll just accept the default,
pause it for one hour.

The automation is now paused.

At that point, when this time runs out,

I have the option to wait the 57 minute

Like I mentioned in the previous video,

now this custom support parameter
monitors your environment
and take corrective action when possible.
And when it's possible,

it will automatically
take corrective actions,

but in cases where it's
not able to recover,
then it will put your RDS Custom instance
into unsupported configuration.

We're going to see an
example of both scenarios.

First, let's see how RDS
Custom correct problem
when it detects.

To initiate that, I want to

to go to services.

RDS Custom instance.

which is currently running.

I wanted to go ahead and
then stop this agent.

So the RDS Custom monitoring
is going to detect that
and it will restart the service
so it's not going to cause any issue
to a RDS Custom instance.
It's now in stop mode
and then if I go back to my RDS Custom,

I won't see any issue because
of my action right there.
If I go back to my RDS Custom console,

I can see that the instance
is still available,

but if I go to the RDS
Custom logs and events,

I will see a new entry

that RDS Custom automation
has found an issue
and then it took a corrective action.

Here is a message telling

action to recover
the RDS Custom agent on your instance.

And now during this time, the
instance is still unaffected.
The status always show as available.

So that's one of the

that RDS Custom automation

is able to take corrective
action when it can.

That is definitely not a supported action
